content:
normally all you would need is the roaming profile. The local stuff should only be cached information

However as you have tinkered with what I am guessing are account "local directories" I suggest you check those in account settings to determine what you have changed them to so you get them all.

Personally I would have moved the profile in the first place. You have used the really easy way to move you data location and now you pay the price of your earlier expedience in changing per account settings instead of the location of the profile.

.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
I was not aware Thunderbird had a message that told you your settings were out of date. Are you sure this was not some setting generated by your antivirus program?

So now instead of trying to fix your accounts, we are trying to set them up anew without the original error message or anything to indicate what the original error message was about or what the problem is. If you wanted to make a difficult job harder, you have achieved that.

Almost every instance I have even seen of this sort of error on setting up a new account where the settings are for a major provider that Thunderbird would have detected from it's database and then could not connect to was a direct result of a failed antivirus product, the remainder were VPN related as they do not play well with email.

Start your OS started in safe mode with Networking. Instructions for each operating system: Windows 10/11, Windows 8, Windows 7, OSX

Now try and add your mail account to Thunderbird. Note that a wired internet connection is required for at least Windows safe mode with networking. So plug your laptop in to the router before you try. WiFi will not be available.

This process should load windows without your antivirus, without your VPN and without any of the normal startup programs, many of which can cause connectivity issues.
creator: MattAuSupport

content: Hi Matt, Thanks for your prompt response. Firstly, I have deleted and re-added accounts in the past to resolve other problems without any issues. In this case it seemed a good solution to try. But it wasn't and you are correct - I am now in deeper water! I had previously paused my Surfshark VPN when attempting to re-add accounts (couldn't use Mozilla VPN as it did not support Australia). This time when trying again I deleted the VPN from my PC and tried again - but still get the same error message. I use the anti-virus feature of Windows and it is still running. When I first start up Thunderbird I get an error message from "Mail" (which I assume is from Thunderbird) saying my Gmail, Yahoo, etc settings are out of date. After inspecting my Mail Settings, which appeared OK, this led me to delete and re-add my Mail accounts. I have tried adding using Thunderbird's automatic feature, and I also looked up the settings for each account and tried adding them manually, but still get the same unsuccessful outcome. The only other thing to note is that I seem to be able to add my Gmail Account successfully, but when I do it starts downloading hundreds (thousands?) of old emails going back years. I can't see how to stop this other than deleting the Gmail account again. I am wondering if this has triggered a spam control feature that has blocked me? I don't know if this feature exists. So I take on board what you are saying about deleting and re-adding my accounts, and I would be interested in what you recommend I should have done - and what I can do next to resolve this problem. Thanks and regards, Graeme

content:
could it be you have consumed the allowable 5 concurrent connections on a single mail server? That is are they all say @gmail.com email addresses? There is no practical limit, but if you have say 5 accounts checking for messages every minute I could see exactly what your a saying happening. The sixth and subsequent connection attempt failing. I see this occasionally on Startup with outlook accounts.

Fundamental email is not an instant messaging platform, despite a lot of people acting like it is.

content:
Thunderbird Support said
Spoke with Nord, they were unable to give me guidance other than to try all the things I already had. They are not blocking POP/IMAP, and SMTP protocols. Also tried split tunneling and that didn't work either.

Have you considered that Google may be refusing you? You have a VPN that is reporting you to be where i the world? And you have a phone without Nord that reports to to be somewhere very different to where NORD is dropping you off. What this is not is a Thunderbird issue. What this is, is a VPN issue.

It is quite simple, if it works without NORD, then the issue is not Thunderbird. It might be your antivirus, it might be your backup solution. But the only common factor you have identified is your VPN.

content:
What are you settings for this account in synchronization & storage?

Do you use any message filters?

My eye is drawn to your folder structure, which makes me wonder if the AOL server is confused.

Why do you have a "Draft" folder and a "Drafts" folder? Why an "Archive" and an "Archives" folder? An AOL account that I have access to uses "Draft" and "Archive". I wonder if these operations would work better if you used those folders.

You might try tests with "Archive" instead of "Archives", and also tests with a new folder called something other than "Archive" and "Archives".

In each case, copy the messages instead of moving them so you won't risk losing them.

Are you using Thunderbird's rules for organizing by year (account settings - copies & folders - archive options)? I don't know how those options would affect what you are doing.

In your place, I would use local folders instead, which may not have this issue, but you might want to keep these messages on the server.

content:
Subject: Re: Missing Emails – Let’s Get Them Back

Dear Chris,

I’m very sorry for your loss. I understand how important these emails are to you, and I’ll do my best to help.

First, just to check—are you using Firefox to access webmail (like Gmail, Yahoo, Outlook) or a separate email app (like Thunderbird, Outlook, or Apple Mail)?

If you’re using a webmail service: 

   Check the Trash or Archive folder – Sometimes emails are moved there by mistake.    Try using the search bar – If you remember a subject line or name, searching might help.    Log in from another device – If you have another computer or phone that was also used for email, check if the emails are there.

If you were using an email program (like Thunderbird): 

   Let me know the name of the email app you were using.    If your husband had backups set up, I can guide you on restoring them.

No worries—we’ll take this step by step. Please reply with any details you can, and I’ll help you as best as I can.

Warm regards,Sakura.

Kedves Attila!

A leírásod alapján nekem úgy tűnik, hogy nem a Thunderbirdben lesz a hiba, ugyanis az alapból sehova sem pakolja a leveleket, csak megjelöli őket (láng ikon a listában).

Mindenesetre a Thunderbird saját levélszemét-kezelését úgy tudod kikapcsolni, hogy a Beállítások -> Adatvédelem és biztonság -> Levélszemét szakaszában az Üzenetek olvasottnak jelölése alatt kikapcsolod a Ha a Thunderbird jelöli levélszemétnek, továbbá az egyes postafiókok alatt a Levélszemét lapon kikapcsolod az Adaptív levélszemét-kezelés engedélyezése ehhez a postafiókhoz lehetőséget (és esetleg a Szolgáltató levélszemétszűrőjének elfogadása lehetőséget, ha van ilyen a postafiókhoz).

Ha ezek mind megvannak, akkor maga a Thunderbird nem végez semmilyen levélszűrést, de ettől függetlenül még a postafiókod lehet hogy csinál ilyet. Például a mailboxos levelezésemet SpamAssassinnal ellenőrzi a szolgáltatóm.

Milyen postafiókról van szó, nem lehet hogy valójában nálad is erről van szó?

Üdv, Balázs

content:
Two screenshots of the font settings in Latin and Other Writing Systems, plus one of a "Finder" window showing the strange fit of the three window-handling button-dots in the upper left, the tiny text of the message-body and Confirm window from within T'bird, and the other places (Window Menu, From) where the text is normal-sized (with Subject larger from within T'bird settings).

The tiny text in messages will zoom up just fine in T'bird, but that's a nuisance for every message (and a strangeness mystery and challenge).

This strangeness started upon migration of T'bird from my old 2013 iMac running MacOS 10.15.n to a 2019 Macbook Pro running MacOS 15.3.1, with the iMac using T'bird 123 or later and the MBP running T'bird 128 (but I am not sure because it is too small for me to read and I can't zoom it). I suspect some dissonance between T'bird and the OS, but all my poking around in MacOS System Settings and changing settings have not resolved this.

All messages, even from long before the migration, are displayed this way.

One clue might be the About Thunderbird window in "Finder," also with tiny text from T'bird in a normal-text window-frame.

I like to pretend that I know my way around Macs and apps, but this one has humbled me.

Please advise.

Thanks, Alexander

content:
Hello Alexander, all your screen shots are misleading since they are displayed much bigger in forums than the original. By default recent macOS versions use a 144 pixel per inch resolution in screen shots versus 72 pixel per inch in earlier versions. I have noticed that when I purchased my first iMac with a Retina 4k screen. All my screen shots were blown up when I sent them or used them in forums. Since several years I regularly edit my screens shots with Preview to resize the images to 50% of their original size. As an exemple I'll show two screen shots of the "About Thunderbird" window, one in the original size and the second resized to about 50% of its original width.

The 3rd image shows my font sizes for Latin, Other writing systems are the same. The 4th image corresponds to your screen shot of a received message displayed in a new window. Maybe you could emphasise with a new screen shot where exactly you need greater text.

creator: AlexanderCarpenter

content:
I admit, this is puzzling. Haven't seen this before. Below is a setting that applies globally, so use TINY increments in experimenting.

  1. exit thunderbird
  2. first make a copy of prefs.js, just in case you have problems.
  3. click tools>settings>general and scroll down to config editor on right side.
  4. enter layout.css.devPixelsPerPx the default is -1.0 try increasing slightly, as it can quickly get too big. try something such a 1.2 or so for starters.
  5. If still too small, increase just a tiny amount, such as 1.8 or 2.0. If you increase to the point that thunderbird is impossible to read because font fills the screen. that is your clue to exit thunderbird, restore the backup of prefs.js and start over.

If you're not sure how to locate prefs.js, do this

  1. - click help>moretroubleshootinginformation
  2. - scroll down to 'Profile folder' and click 'open folder'
  3. - exit thunderbird
  4. - make copy of prefs.js
  5. - restart thunderbird.

content:
Can you post a link to where it says IEEE accounts can't be accessed in TB? I found this article, which indicates that accounts can be added just like any other domain using google servers, e.g. with these settings:

incoming IMAP server: imap.gmail.com, port 993, SSL/TLS, OAuth2 authentication, User Name = user@ieee.org

outgoing SMTP server: smtp.gmail.com, port 465, SSL/TLS, or 587, STARTTLS, OAuth2 authentication, User Name = user@ieee.org

Open the account in webmail and enable IMAP (should be enabled by default).

There are many other free mail services, such as outlook.com, Yahoo, AOL, GMX, all of which are popular with TB users.
